replies.bodyText:
My rule of thumb in general is, assuming a client-server setup, if the server returns an error, the client should log it, not the server. However, the server might log error details that are not returned to the client - i.e. sensitive info, information that isn't helpful for the client, etc.
In this particular case, we return an INTERNAL error to the client (e.g. 500 - which, by the way, is probably the wrong code to return for PARTITION_LEADER_MISMATCH 😅), with very little information from the client point of view. So we need to log it in the broker/gateway. From the broker point of view though, you're right, this is an expected error - hence why I'd log it on the "client" side, i.e. the gateway in this instance. But like I said, bad example, as PARTITION_LEADER_MISMATCH should probably return UNAVAILABLE or something like this, indicating the user can retry the request 😅

chore(gateway): centralize gRPC error mapping

- centralizes gRPC error mapping via ErrorMappingStreamObserver
- wraps EndpointManager behind a GatewayGrpcService which maps
  StreamObserver to ServerStreamObserver for the EndpointManager
- prepares the use of a richer error model described by Google using
  com.google.rpc.Status
